I‚Äòm curious if Rep. Vargas will further explain his stance here that it‚Äôs unacceptable to even *question* US foreign policy.

Plenty of Dem members have asserted that discussion + debate on this issue is fair and merited. Is this stance a departure from that? https://twitter.com/RepJuanVargas/status/1102636576524374016¬†‚Ä¶

It is disturbing that Rep. Omar continues to perpetuate hurtful anti-Semitic stereotypes that misrepresent our Jewish community. Additionally, questioning support for the U.S.-Israel relationship is unacceptable. (1/2)
replies:
I remember a time when it was ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù to question the Iraq War. 

All of Congress was wrong, including both GOP & Dem Party, and led my generation into a disastrous + wrong war that virtually all would come to regret, except for the one member who stood up: Barbara Lee.
(But honestly we shouldn‚Äôt have been in either, and we should end the AUMF now while we‚Äôre at it)

Congresswoman, could you please explain more about what you think the US should have done post-9/11 regarding Afghanistan? Should there not have been any NATO/US action versus AQ/Taliban in your view? A limited one? What would you have supported?

I think that our decision to enter unlimited engagement in Afghanistan, particularly through the AUMF + Congress‚Äô abdication of power + decision-making w/ passage of the AUMF, was a mistake.

Other options: targeting the network itself, limited engagement, non-intervention.
What does non intervention mean? Do you mean us doing nothing? Do you think that‚Äôs the correct course of action after a massive terrorist attack on our soil?

It means not invading an entire nation without end. Doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúdo nothing,‚Äù it means perhaps we could have leaned more on the larger role of other agencies (intelligence, state dept, diplomatic teams, etc) before Congress decided to invade a nation without a concrete end plan.

Not to mention it was US meddling in Afghanistan in the 1980s with the arming of religious fundamentalists to fight the soviets that planted the seeds for what evolved into Al Qaeda, which later carried out 9/11. This was never examined after 9/11
Or when the US decided Al-Quaeda groups in Syria were an occasional ally. Pattern lives on.

Would love for @AOC to sit down with @jockowillink so he could share his experience and why those wars and sacrifices made a difference. I imagine it‚Äôs easy to criticize when you were only 11 years old when 9/11 happened.
That's like saying that historians words aren't valid because they weren't born yet
No, it‚Äôs like saying a historian discussing a war‚Äôs words don‚Äôt carry as much weight as the words of a soldier that fought that war and saw it with his own eyes.

I imagine tho, that a soldier‚Äôs experience on the ground (has a job to do + has to protect his people) is far removed from the decision made by politicians (also not on the ground) whether to engage or not. 

As Bill Hicks said: I was for the soldiers, but against the war.
